assignments.vibrational_mode: E2g in-plane stretching mode of sp2 carbon atoms
assignments.rationale: The frequency at 1579.94 cm⁻¹ is characteristic of the G-band in graphitic materials, representing the in-plane vibration of sp2-bonded carbon atoms in aromatic rings. The relatively broad FWHM (32.54 cm⁻¹) suggests some structural disorder or defects in the graphitic structure.
assignments.literature_reference: Ferrari, A.C. & Robertson, J. (2000). Physical Review B 61, 14095-14107. DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevB.61.14095

assignments.vibrational_mode: C=C stretching vibrations in sp2 clusters
assignments.rationale: Amorphous carbon films show a broad G-band around 1580 cm⁻¹ due to C=C stretching in sp2-bonded carbon clusters. The significant peak width is consistent with the structural disorder typical of amorphous carbon materials.
assignments.literature_reference: Casiraghi, C. et al. (2005). Physical Review B 72, 085401. DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevB.72.085401

assignments.rationale: Single-walled carbon nanotubes exhibit a G-band around 1580 cm⁻¹ corresponding to tangential vibrations of carbon atoms. However, CNTs typically show a narrower linewidth and may exhibit splitting, making this assignment less likely given the observed FWHM.
assignments.literature_reference: Dresselhaus, M.S. et al. (2005). Physics Reports 409, 47-99. DOI: 10.1016/j.physrep.2004.10.006

summary.analysis_overview: The peak at 1579.94 cm⁻¹ with moderate intensity and relatively broad linewidth is most consistent with the G-band of graphitic carbon materials, representing sp2 carbon vibrations in aromatic structures.
summary.key_literature_findings: Extensive literature confirms that the G-band appears around 1580 cm⁻¹ in various carbon materials. Ferrari and Robertson's seminal work established the relationship between G-band position, width, and carbon structure disorder.
summary.alternative_considerations: While amorphous carbon and carbon nanotubes also show peaks in this region, the specific frequency and linewidth characteristics favor graphitic carbon assignment. The absence of a clear D-band discussion limits definitive structural characterization.

references: Ferrari, A.C. & Robertson, J. (2000). Interpretation of Raman spectra of disordered and amorphous carbon. Physical Review B 61, 14095-14107.
Casiraghi, C., Ferrari, A.C., & Robertson, J. (2005). Raman spectroscopy of hydrogenated amorphous carbons. Physical Review B 72, 085401.
Dresselhaus, M.S., Dresselhaus, G., Saito, R., & Jorio, A. (2005). Raman spectroscopy of carbon nanotubes. Physics Reports 409, 47-99.

assignments.vibrational_mode: D' band - disorder-induced overtone of D band, second-order scattering process
assignments.rationale: The frequency at 2670 cm⁻¹ corresponds to the D' band in carbon materials, which appears around 2650-2700 cm⁻¹. This band is an overtone of the D band (~1350 cm⁻¹) and indicates structural disorder in graphitic carbon. The relatively broad FWHM (49.73 cm⁻¹) is consistent with disordered carbon structures.
assignments.literature_reference: Ferrari, A.C. & Robertson, J. (2000). Physical Review B 61, 14095-14107. DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevB.61.14095

assignments.vibrational_mode: C-H stretching vibrations in sp³ hybridized carbon
assignments.rationale: DLC materials can exhibit Raman bands in the 2600-2800 cm⁻¹ region due to C-H stretching modes. The frequency and bandwidth are consistent with hydrogenated amorphous carbon structures containing sp³ bonded carbon atoms.
assignments.literature_reference: Casiraghi, C. et al. (2005). Physical Review B 72, 085401. DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevB.72.085401

assignments.vibrational_mode: Symmetric C-H stretching in alkyl chains or aromatic systems
assignments.rationale: Various organic compounds exhibit C-H stretching vibrations in the 2600-2800 cm⁻¹ range. However, this frequency is somewhat lower than typical alkyl C-H stretches (2850-2950 cm⁻¹), making it less likely unless there are specific electronic or structural effects.
assignments.literature_reference: Socrates, G. (2001). Infrared and Raman Characteristic Group Frequencies. John Wiley & Sons, Chichester.

summary.analysis_overview: The peak at 2670.19 cm⁻¹ with moderate intensity and relatively broad FWHM is most characteristic of the D' band in carbon materials, representing disorder-induced second-order Raman scattering in graphitic structures.
summary.key_literature_findings: Extensive literature on carbon Raman spectroscopy confirms that the D' band appears around 2650-2700 cm⁻¹ and is directly related to structural disorder in graphitic materials. The bandwidth and frequency are well-documented for various carbon allotropes and nanostructures.
summary.alternative_considerations: While DLC materials and organic C-H stretches are possible, the specific frequency and bandwidth characteristics strongly favor the carbon D' band assignment. The frequency is too low for typical organic C-H stretches and the bandwidth is more consistent with carbon materials than with well-defined molecular vibrations.

references: Ferrari, A.C. & Robertson, J. (2000). Interpretation of Raman spectra of disordered and amorphous carbon. Physical Review B 61, 14095-14107.
Casiraghi, C., Ferrari, A.C., & Robertson, J. (2005). Raman spectroscopy of hydrogenated amorphous carbons. Physical Review B 72, 085401.
Socrates, G. (2001). Infrared and Raman Characteristic Group Frequencies: Tables and Charts, 3rd Edition. John Wiley & Sons, Chichester.
